summary: This document is an email chain from February 2020 between US Attorney's Office personnel regarding the status of subpoenas served to multiple airlines and Expedia for travel records related to Ghislaine Maxwell. It details compliance issues, search parameters, and follow-up efforts.

events.title: Subpoena Issued to Expedia
events.description: A subpoena is issued to Expedia for travel records relating to Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Airline Subpoenas Served
events.description: Subpoenas are served to United, Delta, Southwest, American, and Airline Reporting Corp. Plans are made to serve Expedia.

events.title: Airline Subpoena Deadline
events.description: The deadline for airlines to respond to the subpoenas passes.

events.title: Status Update on Subpoena Compliance
events.description: An email provides a status update: responses received from some airlines, pending from others, and issues with Expedia's search requirements.

locations: 28 Liberty Street, New York County (Manhattan), New York, New York 10005
keyFacts: The US Attorney's Office was actively subpoenaing travel records from multiple airlines (United, American, Delta, Alaska, Southwest, JetBlue) and Expedia in relation to Ghislaine Maxwell in early 2020.
Expedia required additional identifiers like email addresses, credit card numbers, or itinerary numbers to search their records, as their database lacked date of birth information.
The investigation faced timing pressure, with a desire to review airline subpoena results before a trip to California.
JetBlue was not served with a subpoena because confidentiality with the airline was not confirmed; it was also noted JetBlue did not begin flying until 2000.
The correspondence indicates the investigation into Maxwell's travel was ongoing and involved detailed logistical follow-up with various corporations.
